text:
Okay so, for the benefit of other people who see this thread. The TL;DR for growing a new B2B Blog is:

1. Focus on thought leadership content. Create a point of veiw that is powerful. Make this your best stuff.
2. Distribute in communities and social. Which means, people will need to play to twitter/reddit/other community game too.
3. Over time, grow DR (How tho? HARO will work here?)
4. Publish crap at 90 DR :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing: (only half joking lol)
Sound right? <@UJG9WTEKG>

Would appreciate your thoughts on point 3.

elements.text: Okay so, for the benefit of other people who see this thread. The TL;DR for growing a new B2B Blog is:
Focus on thought leadership content. Create a point of veiw that is powerful. Make this your best stuff.
Distribute in communities and social. Which means, people will need to play to twitter/reddit/other community game too.
Over time, grow DR (How tho? HARO will work here?)
Publish crap at 90 DR
(only half joking lol)
Sound right?
Would appreciate your thoughts on point 3.

text: thoughts on point 3: do some SEO. the earlier you start the better. thought leadership content is easier to build links to but you want some SEO conetnt around so that you can benefit from the links/DA as they grow

elements.text: thoughts on point 3: do some SEO. the earlier you start the better. thought leadership content is easier to build links to but you want some SEO conetnt around so that you can benefit from the links/DA as they grow

text:
Has anyone experimented with posting blogs directly on LinkedIn's platform?

I know you lose out on all the long-term SEO benefits of hosting it on your own domain, but we are facing a huge uphill battle in a competitive SEO space, so we are thinking about trying to publish directly on LinkedIn and growing an audience there rather than trying to compete for difficult keywords.

Any thoughts on this?

elements.text:
Has anyone experimented with posting blogs directly on LinkedIn's platform?

I know you lose out on all the long-term SEO benefits of hosting it on your own domain, but we are facing a huge uphill battle in a competitive SEO space, so we are thinking about trying to publish directly on LinkedIn and growing an audience there rather than trying to compete for difficult keywords.

Any thoughts on this?

text:
Echoing everything Jimmy said, also focus on building communities that will share your content for you (versus just building a group of followers). Get people in your company proactively using platforms like LinkedIn to build personal brands, and they'll effortlessly send people to your site because people follow people :muscle:

Also completely agree about leveraging email and building a list based on content people actually care about — not just a fun newsletter, but conversational emails that share a ton of value and don't ask anything of anyone. It's slow, but it's a long-game that pays off, especially if you're consistent with content and who it comes from (ties back to those personal brands).

elements.text: Echoing everything Jimmy said, also focus on building communities that will share your content for you (versus just building a group of followers). Get people in your company proactively using platforms like LinkedIn to build personal brands, and they'll effortlessly send people to your site because people follow people

Also completely agree about leveraging email and building a list based on content people actually care about — not just a fun newsletter, but conversational emails that share a ton of value and don't ask anything of anyone. It's slow, but it's a long-game that pays off, especially if you're consistent with content and who it comes from (ties back to those personal brands).

text:
Do it.

I view LinkedIn Pulse as a completely separate entity / strategic play than good ol fashioned on-site blog posts. This is a social media play more than a search play (although over time it's possible you can rank and compete in the SERP). It's definitely worth including in your repurposing toolkit. I've seem good results with it. Make sure you use the hashtags feature though.

elements.text:

text: <@U02RT4NUGPK> also helpful is leveraging peeps within your own org to become thought leaders by repurposing blog content as their own LI posts. They can link to the actual blog articles (wherever you end up hosting them), but they can also offer different insights, more context, etc.

text: Andy Crestodina does a great job of this - he posts on LI a shortened version, then links to the blog for the full post. Here's an example <https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/what-big-content-5-marketing-formats-few-marketers-ever-crestodina/>
